thread indexes are also the row and column indexes for output array

__global__ void MatrixMulKernel (float* M, float* N, float* P, int Width){
    // calculate the row index of the P element and M
    int Row = blockIdx.y * blockDim.y + threadIdx.y;
    // calculate the col index of the P element and N
    int Col = blockIdx.x * blockDim.x + threadIdx.x;

    if((Row < Width) && (Col < Width>)){
        float Pvalue = 0;
        //each thread computes one element of the block sub-matrix
        for(int k = 0; k < Width; k++) {
            Pvalue += M[Row*Width + k] * N[k*Width + Col];
        }
        P[Row * Width + Col] = Pvalue;
    }
}
memory access of the for loop
In every iteration of the loop,
are performed for one floating-point multiplication and one floating-point addition.
One global memory access fetches an M element
the other fetches an N element
One floating-point operation multiplies the M and N elements fetched, and the other accumulates the product into Pvalue.

From our discussion in Chapter 3, Scalable parallel execution, this ratio will likely result in less than 2% utilization of the peak execution speed of the modern GPUs. We need to increase the ratio by at least an order of magnitude for the computation throughput of modern devices to achieve good utilization. In the next section, we will show that we can use special memory types in CUDA devices to accomplish this goal.
Execution of the Matrix Multiplication Kernel Within A Block
blocks that are 2×2 arrays of threads
each thread calculating one P element
The P matrix is now divided into four tiles, and each block calculates one tile.
The picture below illustrates the multiplication operations in each thread block.
Threads in block (0,0) produce four dot products.
